office:text.text:p: "Now, it's my belief that Python is a lot easier than to teach to students programming and teach them C or C++ or Java at the same time because all the details of the languages are so much harder. Other scripting languages really don't work very well there either."

text:list-item.text:p: Avoiding names of keywords and builtins
Sending output (optionally formatted) to the screen
Variables are created when assigned to
May hold any type of data

office:text.text:p: Variables in Python are created by assigning a value to them. They are created and destroyed as needed by the Python interpreter. Variables may hold any type of data â€“ string, numeric, Boolean, or other types. The data type is dynamically determined by the type of data assigned.
Variable names are case sensitive: Spam SPAM and spam are three different variables.
The names of variables may be any length.

A variable must be assigned some value. A value of None (null) may be assigned if no particular value is needed. It is good practice to make variable names consistent. Many Python programmers prefer all_lower_case_with_underscores.

text:list-item.text:p: Python keywords may not be used as variable or function names

office:text.text:p: Python keywords may not be used as identifiers. that is, you can't say and = 5.
On the other hand, Python's builtin functions, such as len() or int() may be used as identifiers, but that will overwrite the builtin's functionality, so you shouldn't do that.

text:p.text:span: Be especially careful not to use
as these are all builtin function names.

text:list-item.text:p: Python is strongly and dynamically typed

office:text.text:p: Python is a typed language. That means that whenever you assign a value to a name, it is given a type. Python has many types built into the interpreter, such as int, str, and float. There are also many packages providing types, such as date, re, or urllib2.
Certain operations are only valid with the appropriate types. Python does not automatically convert strings to numbers or numbers to strings.

text:list-item.text:p: Strings can be raw (escape sequences not interpreted)

office:text.text:p: Python strings are Unicode strings. They can be initialized with several types of string literals.

text:list-item.text:p: Enclosed in pair of single or double quotes

office:text.text:p: Single-delimited strings are enclosed in a pair of single or double quotes.
Escape codes, which start with a backslash, are interpreted specially. This makes it possible to include control characters such as tab and newline in a string.
Single-delimited strings may not contain an embedded newline; that is, they may not be spread over multiple physical lines. They may contain \n, the escape code for a new line.
There is no difference in meaning between single and double quotes. The term "single-quoted" in Python means that there is one quote symbol at each end of the sting literal.
poem = "I think that I will never see\na poem lovely as a tree"

Triple-delimited strings use three double or single quotes at each end of the text. They are the same as single-delimited strings, except that individual single or double quotes are left alone, and that embedded newlines are preserved.
Triple-delimited text is used for text containing literal quotes as well as documentation and boiler-plate text.
Ask your doctor if Python is right for you
The quotes on both ends of the text must match â€“ use either all single or all double quotes, whether it's a normal or a Triple-delimited literal.
If a literal starts with r before the quote marks, then it is a raw string literal. Backslashes are not interpreted.
This is handy if the text to be output contains literal backslashes, such as many regular expression patterns, or Windows paths.
msg = r"please put a newline character (\n) after each line"
This is similar to the use of single quotes in some other languages.

Unicode characters can be specified using either the code point (numeric value) or the name (string). For code points, use \uXXXX, where XXXX is the hex value of the code point. To specify the character name, use \N{name}. Remember escapes are ignored in raw strings.
print('we spent \u20ac1.23M for an original C\u00e9zanne')
we spent â‚¬1.23M for an original CÃ©zanne
See www.unicode.org/charts for lists of Unicode character names

table:table-cell.text:p: Char with octal ASCII value ooo
Character with hex ASCII value hh

text:list-item.text:p: Some builtin functions apply to strings
Modified copies of strings are returned

office:text.text:p: Python has a rich set of operators and methods for manipulating strings.
Methods are called from string objects (variables) using "dot notation" â€“ STR.method().
Strings are immutable â€“ they can not be changed (modified in-place). String functions generally return a modified copy of the string.
String methods may be chained. That is, you can call a string method on the string returned by another method.
If you need a substring function, that will be provided by the slice operation in chapter 5.
String methods may be called on literal strings as well"abc".upper()",".join(some_list)
a = "My hovercraft is full of EELS"
original: My hovercraft is full of EELS
upper: MY HOVERCRAFT IS FULL OF EELS
lower: my hovercraft is full of eels
swapcase: mY HOVERCRAFT IS FULL OF eels
title: My Hovercraft Is Full Of Eels

table:table-cell.text:p: Version of s suitable for caseless comparison
s centered in string of width w, padded with f
s encoded as a bytes object
T if s[i:j] ends with e
s with tabs expanded to t spaces (default 8)
index of 1st occurrence of b in s[i:j]
Return formatted string from s where {} placeholders are replaced with parameters p1, etc
Return formatted string s where {key} placehoders filled in from mapping type m
Like find, but raise ValueError if b not found
T if s contains only letters and digits
T if s contains only letters
T if s contains only decimal characters (same as isdigit() if locale is EN)
T if s contains only digits
T if s is a valid identifier
T if all letters in s are lowercase
T if all letters in s are numeric (any Unicode numeric character)
T if if all characters in the string are printable or the string is empty
T if s contains only whitespace
T if s contains only title cased words (like "Xxxx")
T if all letters in s are uppercase
Elements of sequence m joined with s as delimiter
s left justified in string of width w, padded with f
s with all characters in c stripped from beginning
create a translation table for use with translate()
return tuple with part of s before b, b, part of s after b
s with c occurrences of m replaced with n
Like find() and index(), except return last occurrence
s right justified in string of width w, padded with f
Same as partition(), but last occurrence of b
list of tokens after splitting s on delimiter b
if c specified, at most c splits are done from the right
s with all characters in c stripped from end
list of tokens after splitting s on delimiter b
if c specified, at most c splits are done
T if s[i:j] starts with e
s with all chars in c stripped from both ends
s with case of all letters inverted
s with chars in table t translated
chars in string d deleted if d specified
t must be exactly 256 chars long
s left-padded with zeros to width w

text:list-item.text:p: Integer literals can be decimal, octal, hex, or binary
Floating point can be traditional or scientific notation

text:list-header.text:p: Boolean values can be 1 (true) or 0 (false). The keywords True and False can be used to represent these values, as well.

Integers can be specified as decimal, octal, or hexadecimal. Prefix the number with 0o for octal, or 0x for hex. Integers are signed, and correspond to the natural size of an int on the host computer.

office:text.text:p: Floating point integers may be specified in traditional format or in scientific notation.
Complex numbers may be specified by adding J to the end of the number.

text:list-item.text:p: An operation between and integer and a float results in a float

office:text.text:p: Python has many math operators and functions. Later in this course we will look at some libraries with extended math functionality.
Most of the operators should look familiar; a few may not:
Division (/) always produces a float result.
Python supports C-style assignment-with-operation. For instance, x += 5 adds 5 to variable x. This works for nearly any operator in the format VARIABLE OP=VALUE.
To raise a number to a power, use the ** (exponentiation) operator or the pow() function.
Using the floored division operator //, the result is always rounded down to the nearest whole number. If both operands are integers, the result is an integer; otherwise, the result is a float.
Python does not have the ++ and -- (post-increment and post-decrement) operators common to many languages derived from C.

table:table-cell.text:p: absolute value or magnitude of x
x (decimal) converted to integer; optional base converts strings from hex, binary, octal, or any other base
a complex number with real part re, imaginary part im. im defaults to zero.
conjugate of the complex number c

office:text.text:p: int() convert string or number to integer
float()convert string or number to float

text:list-header.text:p: Python is dynamically typed; if you assign a number to a variable, it will raise an error if you use it with a string operator or function; likewise, if you assign a string, you can't use it with numeric operators.
Python has built-in functions to do these conversions. Use int(s) to convert string s to an integer. Use str(n) to convert anything to a string, and so forth.

office:text.text:p: There are functions to convert to all builtin types; the above four are the most often used.

If the string passed to int() or float() contains characters other that digits or minus sign, a runtime error is raised. Leading or trailing whitespace, however, are ignored. Thus " 123 " is OK, but "123ABC" is not.

text:list-item.text:p: Use sep parameter for alternate separator
Use end parameter for alternate end of string

text:list-header.text:p:
To output text to the screen, use the print function. It takes a list of one or more arguments, and writes them to the screen1
Actually, print outputs to STDOUT, which is the screen unless the script has been redirected.. By default, print() adds a space between the arguments and adds a newline at the end.

office:text.text:p: Two special named arguments can modify the default behavior. The sep argument specifies the output separator, and the end specifies what is written after all the arguments.

text:list-header.text:p: Strings have a format() method for customer formatting of text. Parameters to the format() method are numbered starting with 0, and are formatted by placeholders in the string.
Builtin types to not need to have the type specified, but you may specify the width of the formatted value, the number of decimal points, or other type-specific details.
For instance, {0} will use default formatting for the first parameter. {2:04d} will format the third parameter as an integer, padded with zeros to four characters wide.
There are many more ways of using format(); this discussion describes some of the basics.

office:text.text:p: A placeholder looks like this: {0}, where 0 is the parameter number. To add formatting flags, follow the parameter number with a colon, then the type and other flags. You can also used named parameters, and specify the name rather than the parameter index.
To include literal braces in the string, double them: {{ }}.
For more information, check out the PyDoc topic FORMATTING.
print("NOTICE: version >= 3.1 needed for comma format")

text:list-item.text:p: Use the argv list that is part of the sys module
Element 0 is the script name itself

text:list-header.text:p: To get the command line parameters, use the list sys.argv. This requires importing the sys module. To access elements of this list, use square brackets and the element number. The first element (index 0) is the name of the script, so sys.argv[1] is the first argument to your script.

office:text.text:p: If you use an index for a non-existent parameter, an error will be raised and your script will stop. In later chapters you will learn how to check the size of a list, as well as how to trap the error.

text:list-item.text:p: Use int() or float() to convert input to numeric values

office:text.text:p: To read a line from the keyboard, use input(). The parameter is a prompt string, and it returns the text that was entered. You can use int() or float() to convert the input to an integer or a floating-point number.
What is your name: Sir Lancelot
What is your quest? the Grail
If you use int() or float() to convert a string, a fatal error will be raised if the string contains any non-numeric characters or any embedded spaces. Leading and trailing spaces will be ignored.
Write a script to prompt the user for a Celsius temperature, the print out the Fahrenheit equivalent.
What the user types on the command line:
The program prompts the user, and the user enters the temperature to be converted.
The formula is F = ((9 * C) / 5 ) + 32. Be sure to convert the user-entered value into a float.
Test your script with the following values: 100, 0, 37, -40
Write a Celsius to Fahrenheit converter. Your script should take the Celsius temperature from the command line and output the Fahrenheit value. What the user types on the command line is as follows:
Test with the values from c2f.py.
These two programs should be identical, except for the input source.
Write a script to prompt the user for a full name. Once the name is read in, do the following:

text:list-item.text:p: Print the name in upper case
Print the name in title case
Print the number of occurrences of 'j' (case-insensitive)
Print the length of the name
Print the position (offset) of "jacob" in the string( case-insensitive)

office:text.text:p: Run the program, and enter john jacob jingleheimer smith
